contents.title: Left Coronary artery
content: RAO cranial view is used to see the origins of diagonal branches along the mid and distal LAD. Diagonal branch bifurcations are well visualized.
Diagonal branches are projected upward. The proximal LAD and LCx usually are overlapped. Marginal branches may overlap, and LCx is foreshortened, but posterolateral branches are well visualized.

contents.title: Right Coronary artery
content: In general, RCA is not be seen clearly in RAO Cranial view.

contents.title: Example
content: RAO view can shows the mid RCA and the length of the PDA and posterolateral branches. Septal branches coursing upward from the PDA, supplying occluded LAD artery via collaterals, may be clearly identified without cranial or caudal angulation.

contents.title: Left Coronary artery
content: RAO caudal view shows the LMCA bifurcation, perpendicular to that of the LAO cranial angle. The origin and course of LCx or OM branches and proximal LAD segment are seen clearly. This view is one of the two best for visualization of LCx. LAD beyond the proximal segment is obscured by overlapped diagonals. However, the apical segment of the LAD artery is displayed clearly.

contents.title: Right Coronary artery
content: In general, RCA is not be seen clearly in RAO Caudal view.

contents.title: Example
content: RAO view can shows the mid RCA and the length of the PDA and posterolateral branches. Septal branches coursing upward from the PDA, supplying occluded LAD artery via collaterals, may be clearly identified without cranial or caudal angulation.

contents.title: Left Coronary artery
content: LAO cranial view shows LM (slightly foreshortened), LAD, and its diagonal branches. Septal (coursing to the left) and diagonal branches (to the right) are separated clearly. LCx and OM are foreshortened and overlapped, although the posterolateral and posterior descending branches of left-dominant circulation are displayed clearly.

Deep inspiration, which moves the density of the diaphragm down and out of the field, is helpful. LAO angle (>30 degrees) should be set so that the LAD artery course is parallel to the spine and stays in the “lucent wedge” bordered by the spine on the medial edge and the curve of the diaphragm. Cranial angulation tilts the LM down and permits a view of LAD-LCx bifurcation.
LAO cranial angulation that is too steep or inspiration that is too shallow produces considerable overlapping with the diaphragm and liver, degrading the image.

contents.title: Right Coronary artery
content: LAO cranial view shows the origin of the RCA, the entire length of the mid RCA, the bifurcation of posterior descending artery (the crux of PDA), and also RMA. Cranial angulation tilts the PDA down to see vessel contour and to reduce foreshortening. Deep inspiration is necessary to clear the diaphragm. The PDA and posterolateral branches are slightly foreshortened in this view.

contents.title: Example
content: The cranial angulation of 20° combined with the LAO projection at 55°/60° is especially useful to study the left main coronary artery (LM).

contents.title: Left Coronary artery
content: LAO caudal view (“spider” view) shows LM (foreshortened) and bifurcation of LM into LCx and LAD. Proximal and mid portions of LCx are usually seen clearly with the origins of obtuse marginal branches.
Poor image quality may be caused by overlapping of the diaphragm and spine. LAD is considerably foreshortened in this view.

contents.title: Right Coronary artery
content: LAO projection with caudal angulation allows the whole study of RCA and, especially, clearly defines the region of the crux of the heart.

contents.title: Example
content: Left anterior oblique projection at 45° combined with a caudal angulation of 15° has a clearly spider apperance.

contents.title: Left Coronary artery
content: AP Cranial view is the most useful working projection for angioplasty because treatment can continue in this view without breathholding, which is often required in heavy patients and with suboptimal equipment. The segments which are foreshortened in the AP cranial view include the distal LAD and the proximal left circumflex artery.

contents.title: Right Coronary artery
content: AP cranial view shows the origin of RCA. The mid segment is foreshortened. This is the best view, to display the posterior descending (PDA) and posterolateral (PL) branches of a dominant RCA system and the size of a collateralized LAD artery such as AP 0° Cranial 30°.

contents.title: Left Coronary artery
content: AP 0° caudal 30° view displays the left main coronary artery (LM) in its entire perpendicular length.

In this view, the proximal segments of LAD and LCx are displayed, but the branches are overlapped. After the left main segment, slight RAO or LAO angulation may be need to manage the density of the vertebrae and the catheter shaft in the thoracic descending aorta from covering the artery.

contents.title: Right Coronary artery
content: In general, RCA is not be seen clearly in AP caudal view.
